body:
I've looked a bit at python and it might require actually checking the python executable rather than the libraries it uses. Alacritty itself seems to pass the correct things though and there's no modes set that could cause any issues.

This also seems to happen in tmux though, but no other terminal I've tested shows this behavior.

~Note, tmux was tested in `vte` terminal, which doesn't show this behavior on its own.~

tmux's latest master is updated to set `iutf8` by default(was reverted by accident in the past).
Can you try executing `stty iutf8` before your script? You can just type it in terminal, I guess.

issue.title: Set IUTF8 input setting on supported platforms

body:
> I've looked a bit at python and it might require actually checking the python executable rather than the libraries it uses.

This utf-8 error also arises when using Rust instead of Python

> Can you try executing `stty iutf8` before your script? You can just type it in terminal, I guess.

Did it, the error is still there

>Did it, the error is still there

could you type `stty` after that and show me the output of it? There's no way it doesn't fixes the issue, since it's exactly encoding thing.

Seems like you're doing it wrong?

After doing `stty iutf8`, the output of `stty` should be like.
```
speed 38400 baud; line = 0;
-brkint -imaxbel iutf8
```

> Seems like you're doing it wrong?

![Снимок экрана от 2020-05-27 01-29-18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29727534/82956577-c1f44a00-9fb9-11ea-9d80-1adaa7c56a47.png)

Interesting, so yeah, that's why it's not working, could you try #3770 ? I'm not entirely sure why `stty` is no-op for you, but anyway.

I'll assume your other terminal has it in output by default, so if you type `stty` in it, it should show `iutf8`.

Zsh, for example, can "freeze" the terminal settings (with `ttyctl -f`). Any changes to the terminal attributes after that are non-persistent.

https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Zsh#The_ttyctl_command

>Zsh, for example, can "freeze" the terminal settings (with ttyctl -f). Any changes to the terminal attributes after that are non-persistent.

Oh, if it's zsh then yes, that could be the case, but it shouldn't do that by default, unless you have tons of configs, not written by you or whatever. Though, I have no idea what shell is being used here, and default zsh comes with plain config.

I'd recommend to try `alacritty -e bash` then or mentioned PR.

issue.title: Incorrect multibyte string crop on backspace

repository.name: tilda
repository.description: A Gtk based drop down terminal for Linux and Unix

issue.body:
I'm trying to send Cyrillic chars using netcat. 

There is no problem with Latin chars, but when backspacing Cyrillic string, getting wrong encoding sent.
In logs, it looks like `\D0` and `\D1` warnings that could not be converted to valid UTF-8 data.

No problem with other terminals. Suppose that's bug related to bytes length calculation.

Also found no option for [VTE_ERASE_AUTO](https://developer-old.gnome.org/vte/unstable/VteTerminal.html#VteEraseBinding) mode even defined

Debian 12 / i3, repository version, `ASCII DEL` in `Compatibility` settings
